Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Mathematical Statistics and Applications: From Time Series and Stochastics, to Semi- and Non-Parametrics, to High-Dimensional Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "Symposium on Mathematical Statistics and Applications: From Time Series and Stochastics, to Semi- and Non-Parametrics, to High-Dimensional Models" held September 14 - 16, 2018 at Michigan State University. This conference is designed to benefit graduate students and early-career researchers in mathematical statistics. As the data revolution of the 21st century takes the US to new frontiers in data-based decision-making and predictive analytics in business and government, the role of the mathematically-trained and analytically-critical statistician remains more important than ever, to develop and analyze sound, innovative ways of understanding data science algorithms, methodologies, and procedures. The conference will bring together established and aspiring researchers from around the country and abroad to explore frontiers of mathematical statistics and a host of emerging applications. The exposure and networking opportunities provided by the conference to the dozens of graduate students and early-career researchers will be of great value, and potentially career-changing for some.

Foundational work to further develop the analysis and use of data in all its forms is underway in several areas, particularly in semi- and non-parametric statistics. Such mathematical development is needed across a wide spectrum of the statistical sciences, including high-dimensional statistical inference, non-parametric time series, functional data analysis, empirical processes, and machine learning. The conference will expose the participants to these topics as well as other directions, including asymptotic theory of adaptive and efficient estimation, time series in econometrics, and survival analysis. With ample time built into the schedule for discussions, the conference will give participants opportunities to engage in fruitful cross-group collaborations. A particularly impactful aspect of the conference is the inclusion of several presentations by local non-statisticians who work in areas typically underserved by statisticians but with very significant data analysis needs, all interested in interacting with statisticians from across the country with whom there would ordinarily be no chance to meet. Application areas covered will include quantitative finance, insurance mathematics and risk analytics, nuclear physics, agricultural economics, neuro-imaging, soil science, hospital management, hydrology, and others. The conference website is https://stt.msu.edu/MSUStatSymposium2018/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was to organizer a 3-day meeting on recent advances in mathematical statistics and applications. It was held from September 14 to September 16, 2018, at Michigan State University (MSU). 136 scholars, both early-career and well-established, traveld from across the country and across the world to come to this conference, and 71 of them gave oral or poster presentations. One of the meeting's major outcomes was to combine some of the country's leading scholars in semi- and non-paramtric statistics, time series analysis, and inference for stochastic processes, with scholars from several fields outside of statistics who are open to new ways of using high-level statistics in their work, particularly when their applied communities are underserved by statisticians. This was done by running five invited special sessions on applied topics, including on areas in healthcare management, human medicine, nuclear physics, and computational science. Those sessions highlighed the great work which is going on in applied statistics in these areas at MSU. A unique aspect of the meeting was to honor the scientific career of Prof. Hira L. Koul, whose influence on mathematical statistics is decades-long andworld-wide, and continues strongly to this day. The meeting's main practical outcomes was to serve many undergraduates, graduate students, and other early-career researchers in statistics who attended, by providing them with opportunities to network, to learn about activity on highly non-trivial aspects of their field, and to discover a breadth of applied work directions, relevant to their interests in mathematical statistics, which most do not suspect exists. Many of these dozens of early-career researchers, including students, siezed on the opportunity to present their work in the context of this high-profile conference.
